analyzed: yaḥ duḥkha hetu vyupaśānti mārgam pradarśayāmāsa nara amarebhyaḥ
translated: He who showed the path of the cessation of the cause of suffering to humans and immortals,

original: taṃ satpathajñaṃ praṇipatya buddhaṃ śāstraṃ kariṣyāmyabhidharmadīpam // Abhidh //
analyzed: tam sat patha jñam praṇipatya buddham śāstram kariṣyāmi abhidharma dīpam
translated: Having bowed to that Buddha, the knower of the true path, I will compose this treatise, the Lamp of Abhidharma.

analyzed: sattva ādi ananyathābhāve vyakta abhāvaḥ prasajyate
translated: If there is no otherness of existence, etc., the non-existence of manifestation would follow.

analyzed: tad vikārāt vikāri tvam prakṛteḥ tad abhedataḥ
translated: Because of its modification, modification would follow, due to the non-difference of the primordial nature from that.

analyzed: na karma svaka tā utsargāt jña vyakta ātmaka tā malāḥ
translated: Karma is not due to the abandonment of its own nature. The defilements are not of the nature of knowledge and manifestation.

analyzed: prākpakṣe mukti abhāvaḥ ca dvitīye nye pi upaplavāḥ
translated: In the first case, there would be no liberation. In the second case, there would be other calamities as well.

analyzed: rūpa skandhaḥ hi netra ādyāḥ daśa āyatana dhātavaḥ
translated: The form aggregate is the ten sense bases and elements beginning with the eye.

analyzed: dharma saṃjñe traya skandhāḥ sa a vijñaptiḥ dhruva trayāḥ
translated: The three aggregates with the name of dharmas, along with the non-informative, are the three constant ones.

analyzed: sapta vijñānadhātavaḥ
translated: The mind called manas is also the other seven consciousness elements.

analyzed: āya dvāram hi āyatanam dhātuḥ gotram nirucyate
translated: The sense base is said to be the door of entry. The element is said to be the lineage.

analyzed: yoga rūpya ānukūlya ādeḥ dvādaśāyatanīm muniḥ
translated: The Sage, for the sake of suitability with the yoga of form, etc.,

analyzed: buddhi ādi ekatva dhī hānyai dhātūn ca aṣṭādaśa uktavān
translated: Has stated the sense bases to be twelve, and the elements to be eighteen, for the sake of abandoning the notion of unity of intellect, etc.

analyzed: ṣaṇṇām anyaḥ nya tantra tvāt kāraṇam yat hi tat manaḥ
translated: The mind is the cause of the six [sense-fields], because they are dependent on it.

analyzed: rūpya rūpa āśraya astitvāt pañcānām rūpī udāhṛtaḥ
translated: The five [sense-fields] are said to be based on form and formlessness.

analyzed: skandha āyatana dhātūnām sva ātmanā saṃgrahaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The aggregates, sense-fields, and elements are known to be included by their own nature.

analyzed: sva ātmanā nityam aviyogāt samatvam citta caitasām
translated: The mind and mental factors are always equal, because they are inseparable by their own nature.

analyzed: tad ākhyāḥ ye teṣām eṣu eva saṃgraham
translated: Those mentioned in other sūtras with those names are included in these [aggregates, sense-fields, and elements].

analyzed: brūyāt śāstra naya abhijñaḥ buddhyā apekṣya sva lakṣaṇam
translated: One who knows the method of the treatise should speak, considering their own characteristics with wisdom.

analyzed: anyonya saṃgrahaḥ jñeyaḥ skandha ādīnām yathāyatham
translated: The mutual inclusion of the aggregates and so on should be known as appropriate.

analyzed: na adhva sva patana ādibhyaḥ nityānām skandha saṃgrahaḥ
translated: The eternal [dharmas] are not included in the aggregates, because they do not fall into the time periods and so on.

analyzed: dharma skandha sahastrāṇām aśīteḥ api saṃgrahaḥ
translated: The inclusion of even eighty thousand dharma aggregates

analyzed: jñeyaḥ vataraṇeṣu eva taiḥ sat mārga avatāraṇāt
translated: should be known in the Avataṃsaka, because the true path is entered through them.

analyzed: dharma skandha pramāṇam tu satya ādeḥ ekaśas kathā
translated: The measure of the dharma aggregate is discussed individually for each truth and so on.

analyzed: tat sa tattvam tu keṣāñcid vāc nāmā api iṣyate paraiḥ
translated: But the true nature of that [dharma aggregate] is considered by some others to be only speech and name.

analyzed: sattva prajñapti upādānam maulam ṣaṣ dhātavaḥ matāḥ
translated: The fundamental bases for the designation of sentient beings are considered to be the six fundamental elements.

analyzed: proktāḥ tad bhedataḥ yasmāt asmimānaḥ nivartate
translated: Because they are said to be its varieties, from which conceit turns away.

original: kliṣṭameva hi vijñānaṃ draṣṭavyaṃ janmani śrayāt /
analyzed: kliṣṭam eva hi vijñānam draṣṭavyam janmani śrayāt
translated: Only defiled consciousness should be seen as the basis for rebirth, because it is the cause of rebirth.

original: khadhātuḥ pṛthagākāśādrūpāyatanasaṃgrahāt // Abhidh //🔽nabhaḥ khalu nabho dhātorāsanno hetureṣa tu /
analyzed: kha dhātuḥ pṛthak ākāśāt rūpa āyatana saṃgrahāt  nabhaḥ khalu nabhaḥ dhātoḥ āsannaḥ hetuḥ eṣa tu
translated: The space element is separate from space, because it is included in the form aggregate.

original: bhūtānāṃ tāni tajjasya rūpasyaitattu cetasaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: bhūtānām tāni tad jasya rūpasya etat tu cetasaḥ
translated: Space is indeed the proximate cause of the space element, but this [space element] is the cause of the great elements. Those [great elements] are the cause of the form derived from them, but this [space element] is the cause of the mind.

analyzed: pratyakṣa vṛttiḥ yat tat prāk aprāpta grāhyataḥ pi yat
translated: That which has direct activity is the first, because it grasps objects that were not previously obtained.

analyzed: yat davīyaḥ ṛtham paṭiṣṭham itarāt api
translated: Even from that, the object that is farthest is the most manifest, even from the other.
The visible is the first object. The ten with form are resistant.

original: anyatra rūpaśabdābhyāṃ ta evāvyākṛtā matāḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: anyatra rūpa śabdābhyām te eva avyākṛtāḥ matāḥ
translated: Those same [elements] are considered neutral, except for form and sound.

analyzed: śeṣāḥ tridhā iha sarve rūpadhātau caturdaśa
translated: The rest are threefold here. In the form realm, there are fourteen.

original: rasagandhau savijñānau dhātū hitvā trayontimāḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: rasa gandhau sa vijñānau dhātū hitvā trayaḥ antimāḥ
translated: Taste and smell with consciousness, excluding the last three elements.

analyzed: sa āsrava anāstravāḥ antyāḥ trayaḥ śeṣāḥ tu sa āsravāḥ
translated: The last three are with and without outflows. The rest are with outflows.

analyzed: sa ālamba prathamāḥ pañca sa upacārāḥ trayaḥ tridhā
translated: The first five have objects. The last three are threefold, with and without preparation.

analyzed: nirvikalpa guṇa sva arthāḥ asmārāt anirūpaṇāt
translated: The mind is non-conceptual, has the nature of its own object, is without memory, and does not determine.

original: manobhaumī smṛtiḥ pūrvo dvitīyo dhīrnirūpikā // Abhidh //
analyzed: manaḥ bhaumī smṛtiḥ pūrvaḥ dvitīyaḥ dhīḥ nirūpikā
translated: Memory is of the earth of the mind, the first is non-determining, the second is determining.

analyzed: vijñāna pañcakam kāmeṣu ekena sa vikalpakam
translated: In the desire realm, the five consciousnesses are conceptual with one,

original: tasmādanyat tribhiḥ dhyāne prathame cāsamāhitam // Abhidh //
analyzed: tasmāt anyat tribhiḥ dhyāne prathame ca asamāhitam
translated: with the other three in the first dhyāna, and the uncollected mind.

analyzed: dvābhyām avyagram ekena cakṣuḥ śrotra tvac āśrayam
translated: With two, the eye, ear, and body consciousnesses are unperturbed, with one, the mind consciousness.

analyzed: dvābhyām tad upari vyagram ekena eva samāhitam
translated: With two, the uncollected mind and the mind consciousness are perturbed, with one, the collected mind.

analyzed: ucchinna śubha bījasya darśanam sa vikalpakam
translated: For one whose seed of good has been cut off, the seeing is conceptual.

analyzed: kuśalam na asti vijñānam anyatra pratisandhitaḥ
translated: There is no wholesome consciousness except at the time of rebirth-linking.

analyzed: kāmebhyaḥ vīta rāgasya bālasya a hāni dharmiṇaḥ
translated: For one detached from the desire realm, a fool with the nature of decline,

original: dvidhāpyakuśalaṃ nāsti kliṣṭaṃ cāryasya nottamam // Abhidh //🔽nākliṣṭāvyākṛtaṃ kiñcidūrdhvabhūmivikalpakam /
analyzed: dvidhā api akuśalam nā asti kliṣṭam ca āryasya nā uttamam  na akliṣṭa avyākṛtam kiñcid ūrdhva bhūmi vikalpakam
translated: there is no unwholesome in either way, and for an ārya, no afflicted supreme.🔽There is no afflicted or neutral conceptual consciousness pertaining to higher realms.

analyzed: kliṣṭam vikalpakam ca api na asti adhas bhūmi gocaram
translated: And there is no conceptual afflicted consciousness pertaining to lower realms.

analyzed: tridhā iha dvayam āryasya rāgiṇaḥ sa śubhasya ca
translated: For an ārya, there are three kinds, and for one with passion, one with good.

original: na śubhaṃ nāpi ca kliṣṭaṃ dvitīyādiṣu darśakam // Abhidh //
analyzed: na śubham na api ca kliṣṭam dvitīya ādiṣu darśakam
translated: Neither pure nor defiled, it is the cause of memory in the second moment and onwards.

analyzed: prayogāt aṅga sānnidhyāt sabhāga tvāt ca santateḥ
translated: From the proximity of the limbs of application, and from the homogeneity of the continuum,

analyzed: prāk vijñāna anubhūte rthe cetasi utpadyate smṛtiḥ
translated: Memory arises in the mind regarding an object previously experienced by consciousness.

analyzed: etad viparyayāt māndyāt kleśa roga abhibhūtitaḥ
translated: From the opposite of this, from weakness, from being overwhelmed by afflictions and diseases,

analyzed: jñāta pūrveṣu vismṛtiḥ saṃprajāyate
translated: Forgetfulness arises regarding what was known before.

analyzed: dṛṣṭam dvi tri catur pañca prakāreṇa api cetasā
translated: What was seen by a mind of two, three, four, or five types

analyzed: smaryate sat tad anyaiḥ ca na anyaḥ vyogha dṛś kṣaye
translated: is remembered by that and others, but not by others when the eye-consciousness is destroyed.

analyzed: vijñānānām tu pañcānām yat ekena anubhūyate
translated: But what is experienced by one of the five consciousnesses

analyzed: tat smaryate ca anyena tena khalu itaraiḥ api
translated: is remembered by another, and also by that one, and by the others.

analyzed: dvi avyākṛta anubhūtam yat cittam dvādaśakāt iha
translated: What was experienced by a mind of two indeterminate [types] here,

analyzed: vyārūpya rūpa nivṛteḥ smaryate ṣṭābhiḥ eva tat
translated: that is remembered by eight, excluding the formless and obscured [types].

analyzed: rūpa ārūpya āpta nivṛta śubhābhyām tu krameṇa yat
translated: But what is remembered by the two, the obscured and pure [types] obtained in the form and formless [realms], respectively,

original: kāmāptāvyākṛte hitvā smaryate daśakena tat // Abhidh //
analyzed: kāma āpta avyākṛte hitvā smaryate daśakena tat
translated: that is remembered by the ten, excluding the indeterminate and form realm [types] obtained in the desire [realm].

analyzed: rūpe tu anivṛta ākhyena dṛṣṭam avyākṛtena yat
translated: In the case of form, what is seen by the undefiled is called unobstructed.

original: ārūpyāvyākṛte hitvā tadanyaiḥ smaryate punaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: ārūpya avyākṛte hitvā tad anyaiḥ smaryate punar
translated: In the form realm, what is seen by the neutral one called unobstructed is remembered again by all except for the neutral of the formless realm.

analyzed: ārūpya avyākṛta jñātam yaḥ cetaḥ navakena tat
translated: What is known as neutral in the formless realm is that by the nine consciousnesses.

analyzed: kāma āpta avyākṛte hitvā rūpa āpta anivṛtam tathā
translated: Except for what is neutral in the desire realm and likewise the unobstructed in the form realm.

analyzed: citta ākhyāḥ sapta sa ālambāḥ dharma ākhyaḥ saṃprayuktakaḥ
translated: The seven called mind are with objects. The one called dharma is associated.

original: amūrtā dhvaninā sārdhamanupāttāḥ nava dvidhā // Abhidh //
analyzed: amūrtāḥ dhvaninā sārdham anupāttāḥ nava dvidhā
translated: The formless ones along with sound are twofold: the nine are not conjoined.

original: spṛśyaṃ dvidhā sadharmāṃśāḥ saha tā nava bhautikāḥ /
analyzed: spṛśyam dvidhā sadharma aṃśāḥ saha tāḥ nava bhautikāḥ
translated: The tangible is twofold. Along with the dharma part, they are the nine elements.

original: daśa sāvayavā mūrtāḥ ta eva daśa saṃcitāḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: daśa sāvayavāḥ mūrtāḥ te eva daśa saṃcitāḥ
translated: The ten with parts are the material ones. Those same ten are the accumulated ones.

analyzed: rūpa gandha rasa sparśāḥ chetṛ chedya ātmakāḥ matāḥ
translated: Form, smell, taste, and touch are considered to have the nature of what is cut and what cuts.

analyzed: dāhakāḥ tolakāḥ ca ete dāhyāḥ tolyāḥ te eva vā
translated: These are what burns and what weighs, or they are what is to be burned and what is to be weighed.

analyzed: pañca rūpi indriya ātmānaḥ vipāka upacaya ātmakāḥ
translated: The five are of the nature of the material sense faculties. They are of the nature of fruition and accumulation.

original: amūrtā naupacayikāḥ tridhā śeṣāḥ dhvanirdvidhā // Abhidh //
analyzed: amūrtāḥ na aupacayikāḥ tridhā śeṣāḥ dhvaniḥ dvidhā
translated: The formless ones are not of accumulation. The rest are threefold. Sound is twofold.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ tad upalabdhiḥ ca pṛthak vā saha vā āpnuyāt
translated: The eye and its perception may attain separately or together.

analyzed: dvādaśa ādhyātmikāḥ jñeyāḥ bāhya aṣṣaṣ viṣaya ātmakāḥ
translated: The twelve are to be known as internal, the six external as objects.

analyzed: trayaḥ ntyāḥ trividhāḥ śeṣāḥ bhāvanā patha saṃkṣayāḥ
translated: The last three are of three kinds, the rest are destroyed by the path of cultivation.

original: na rūpamasti dṛggheyaṃ nākliṣṭaṃ nāvikalpakam // Abhidh //
analyzed: na rūpam asti dṛś heyam na akliṣṭam na avikalpakam
translated: There is no form to be abandoned by seeing, nor is it defiled, nor is it non-discriminating.

analyzed: sa bhāgaḥ eva dharma ākhyaḥ śeṣāḥ tu ubhayathā smṛtāḥ
translated: The one called dharma is only similar, the rest are remembered as both.

analyzed: sa bhāgaḥ tad sa bhāga tve sva kriyā bhāj tu tulyate
translated: Similar means having the same function, but equality is due to the absence of action.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ sa dharmadhātu aṃśam navadhā dṛṣṭiḥ ūcyate
translated: The eye and the part of the element of dharmas are said to be ninefold vision.

analyzed: pāñcavijñānakī prajñā na dṛṣṭiḥ an iti īraṇāt
translated: The wisdom of the five consciousnesses is not vision, because it does not investigate.

analyzed: sa meghā megha rātri ahnoḥ dṛśyam cakṣuḥ yathā īkṣate
translated: Just as the eye sees the visible in the night and day with and without clouds,

analyzed: kliṣṭa akliṣṭa dṛśau tadvat śaikṣa aśaiṃkṣe ca paśyataḥ
translated: one sees with defiled and undefiled vision, and with learner's and non-learner's vision.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ paśyati vijñānam vijānāti sva gocaram
translated: The eye sees, consciousness cognizes its own domain.

analyzed: ālocanā upalabdhi tvāt viśeṣaḥ su mahān tayoḥ
translated: The difference between them is very great, because one is perception by investigation, the other by apprehension.

analyzed: ekasya cakṣuṣaḥ kāryam vijñānam athavā dvayoḥ
translated: The function of one eye is consciousness, or of two.

original: aprāpyārthaṃ manaścakṣuḥ śrotraṃ ca trīṇyato 'nyathā // Abhidh //
analyzed: a prāpya artham manaḥ cakṣuḥ śrotram ca trīṇi atas nyathā
translated: The mind, eye, and ear apprehend objects without contact, the other three are otherwise.

analyzed: aprāpta grāhiṇaḥ siddhāḥ dūra āsanna sama grahāt
translated: It is established that [the sense faculties] apprehend objects not yet in contact, because distant and near objects are apprehended equally.

analyzed: pradīpa ādi prabhāvaḥ ced na samam tad samudbhavāt  sarva graha prasaṃgaḥ ced na ayaskānta ādi darśanāt
translated: If it is argued that the light of a lamp, etc. is the cause, that is not equal, because it arises from that.🔽If it is argued that there would be the fault of apprehending everything, that is not so, because of the example of a magnet, etc.

analyzed: sarvaga tvāt adoṣaḥ ced na ayogāt tila taila vat
translated: If it is argued that there is no fault because of omnipresence, that is not so, because of non-connection, like sesame oil and sesame seeds.

original: na hyūrdhvaṃ cakṣuṣaḥ kāyo na rūpaṃ nākṣijaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: na hi ūrdhvam cakṣuṣaḥ kāyaḥ na rūpam na akṣi jam manaḥ
translated: The body is not above the eye, nor is form, nor is the mind born from the eye.

original: vijñānasya tu netrārthastau ca kāyasya savaṃtaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: vijñānasya tu netra arthaḥ tau ca kāyasya
translated: But for consciousness, the object of the eye, and those two are the body's own.

original: nopariṣṭācchru teḥ kāyo na śabdo na svakaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: na upariṣṭāt śru teḥ kāyaḥ na śabdaḥ na svakam manaḥ
translated: The body is not above the ear, nor is sound, nor is one's own mind.

original: vijñānasya tu nihrādastau ca kāyasya sarvataḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: vijñānasya tu nihrādaḥ tau ca kāyasya sarvatas
translated: But for consciousness, the roar, and those two are everywhere in the body.

analyzed: trayāṇām trīṇi api svāni tanoḥ vijñānam api adhas
translated: For the three, the three are their own, and for the body, consciousness is also below.

analyzed: manaḥ tu aniyatam yogi vaiśvarūpyam pradarśitam
translated: But the mind is not fixed, the variety of yogis is shown.

analyzed: sa āsrava anāsrāḥ skandhāḥ ye tu upādāna saṃjñitāḥ
translated: Those aggregates called upādāna, which are with and without outflows,

analyzed: sa āsravāḥ eva te jñeyāḥ tad sācivya kriyā ādibhiḥ
translated: should be known as only with outflows, by the function of assisting them, etc.

analyzed: adhva ādyāḥ skandha paryāyāḥ dharma ādyāḥ vastunaḥ sataḥ
translated: The aggregates, etc. are synonyms for the three times, etc., and dharma, etc. are for the existent entity.

original: ye tu sāsravasaṃjñāste proktā duḥkhādināmabhiḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: ye tu sa āsrava saṃjñāḥ te proktāḥ duḥkha ādi nāmabhiḥ
translated: But those that are with outflows are called by the names of suffering, etc.

analyzed: svātmya gocara kāryāṇām eka tvāt eka dhātu tā
translated: Because of the oneness of the object, function, and basis, there is the oneness of the element.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi dvi bhāve pi dvi utpattiḥ karma tri tva śāt
translated: Even when the eye, etc. are twofold, there is twofold arising due to the threefoldness of action.

analyzed: a sādhāraṇa vaiśiṣṭyāt aiśvaryāt ā antaraṅgayataḥ
translated: Because of the special superiority of the uncommon, and because of the internal organ due to sovereignty,

analyzed: sati api aneka hetu tve vijñānam taiḥ viśeṣyate
translated: even though there are many causes, consciousness is distinguished by them.

analyzed: nitya tvāt kuśala tvāt ca nirvāṇam dravyam añjasā
translated: Because of eternality and because of wholesomeness, nirvana is truly a substance.

analyzed: sāra dravyena tena ekaḥ dharma ākhyaḥ dravyavān mataḥ
translated: By that substantial essence which is the essence, it is considered to be one, called dharma, possessing a substance.

analyzed: prathamam nirmalam cittam asābhāgyāt kṣaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: The first pure mind is considered a moment due to the lack of a part of the darkness.

analyzed: tena adbhuta kṣaṇena ete kṣaṇikāḥ paścimāḥ trayaḥ
translated: By that wonderful moment, these last three are momentary.

analyzed: ghrāṇam jihvā ca kāyaḥ ca tulya artha grāhya daḥ trayam
translated: The nose, tongue, and body, the three that grasp objects of equal substance,

original: paścimasyāśrayo 'tītaḥ pañcānāṃ taiḥ sahāpi ca // Abhidh //
analyzed: paścimasya utītaḥ pañcānām taiḥ saha api ca
translated: the basis of the last one is past, and also together with the five.

analyzed: niśritya khalu anāgamyam niśrayān caturaḥ vā
translated: Indeed, relying on the preliminary stage, or on the four bases,

analyzed: anāsraveṇa mārgeṃṇa cakṣuḥ dhātuḥ nirudhyate
translated: by the undefiled path, the eye element is ceased.

analyzed: anāgamyam tu niśritya gandhadhātuḥ nirudhyate
translated: But based on the preliminary stage, the odor element ceases.

analyzed: manaḥ dhātuḥ anāgamyam yadi vā sapta niśrayāt
translated: The mind element, if based on the preliminary stage or the seven stages,

analyzed: anāgamyam tathā eva ādyam cakṣuḥ vijñāna saṃjñakaḥ
translated: The preliminary stage, and likewise the first, called eye consciousness,

analyzed: dharmadhātoḥ vicitra tvāt yathāyogam vinirdiśet
translated: The dharma element should be explained according to the appropriate variety.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ dhātum hi rūpa āptam parijānan pṛthagjanaḥ
translated: For a worldling who fully understands the eye element belonging to the form realm,

analyzed: kṛtsnāt rūpa mayāt dhātoḥ vairāgyam adhigacchati
translated: He attains detachment from the entire form-based realm.

analyzed: tasmāt anuśayān dhātoḥ ekatriṃśat jahāti ca
translated: Therefore, from that element with latent tendencies, he abandons thirty-one.

original: paryādatte na kiñcittu saṃyojanamasau tadā // Abhidh //
analyzed: paryādatte na kiñcid tu saṃyojanam asau tadā
translated: But at that time, he does not abandon any fetter at all.

analyzed: rūpa vairāgyam āpnoti jahāti anuśaya trayam
translated: He attains detachment from the form realm and abandons the three latent tendencies.

original: tadā saṃyojanaṃ tvāryaḥ paryādatte na kiñcana // Abhidh //
analyzed: tadā saṃyojanam tu āryaḥ paryādatte na kiñcana
translated: But at that time, the noble one does not abandon any fetter at all.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vijñāna dhātum tu parijānan tam eva ca
translated: But one who fully understands the eye consciousness element and that very [eye element],

analyzed: parijānāti avaśyam ca brahma lokāt virajyate
translated: He necessarily fully understands and becomes detached from the Brahma world.

original: na tu saṃyojanaṃ kiñcitparyādatte tadā hyasau /
analyzed: na tu saṃyojanam kiñcid paryādatte tadā hi asau
translated: But at that time, he does not abandon any fetter at all.

original: gandhadhātuṃ rasākhyaṃ ca parijānan pṛthagjanaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: gandha dhātum rasa ākhyam ca parijānan pṛthagjanaḥ
translated: An ordinary person, fully understanding the odor element and the taste element,

analyzed: kāma vairāgyam āpnoti dhruvam hi anuśayān api
translated: attains detachment from the desire realm, certainly also abandoning the latent tendencies.

analyzed: tadā jahāti ṣaṭtriṃśat varti saṃyojana trayam
translated: At that time, he abandons thirty-six fetters and three latent tendencies.

analyzed: āryaḥ tu kāma vairāgyam karoti anuśayān api
translated: But an ārya, attaining detachment from the desire realm, also abandoning the latent tendencies,

original: caturaḥ parijānāti paryādatte 'pi ca trayam // Abhidh //
analyzed: caturaḥ parijānāti paryādatte ca trayam
translated: fully understands four [truths], and also abandons three [types of fetters].

analyzed: parijānan manaḥ dhātum ārūpyebhyaḥ virajyate
translated: Fully understanding the mind element, he becomes detached from the formless realms.

analyzed: jahāti anuśayān trīn ca paryādatte trayam tathā
translated: He abandons three latent tendencies, and likewise abandons three [types of fetters].

analyzed: parijānan khalu tām eva prajahāti asau
translated: Indeed, fully understanding joy, he abandons just that.

original: ābhāsvarācca vairāgyaṃ yāti hanti tu nāsravān // Abhidh //
analyzed: ābhāsvarāt ca vairāgyam yāti hanti tu na āsravān
translated: From the Ābhāsvara heaven, he attains detachment, but does not destroy the defilements.

analyzed: parijānan sukham yogī prajahāti tat eha ca
translated: The yogin, fully understanding pleasure, abandons that too.

original: śubhakṛtsnācca vairāgyaṃ yāti kleśānna hanti tu // Abhidh //
analyzed: śubhakṛtsnāt ca vairāgyam yāti kleśān na hanti tu
translated: From the Śubhakṛtsna heaven, he attains detachment, but does not destroy the defilements.

original: dvivijñeyāḥ guṇāḥ pañca hetuḥ sarve kṣarākṣarāḥ /
analyzed: dvivijñeyāḥ guṇāḥ pañca hetuḥ sarve kṣarākṣarāḥ
translated: The five qualities are to be known in two ways. All are causes, perishable and imperishable.

analyzed: anyatra dharmadhātu ardhāt śaṃ bāhyāḥ na indriya ātmakāḥ
translated: Except for half of the dharma element, the other six external [elements] are not of the nature of faculties.

analyzed: dvāviṃśati prakārasya kṛtsnasya indriya parvaṇaḥ
translated: Of the entire treatise on the faculties, which has twenty-two chapters,

analyzed: saṃkṣepeṇa abhidhāsyante dharmāḥ nirvacana ādayaḥ
translated: The dharmas such as verbal expression will be briefly explained.

original: nāmnā dvāviṃśatistāni dravyato daśa sapta ca /
analyzed: nāmnā dvāviṃśatiḥ tāni dravyataḥ daśa sapta ca
translated: By name there are twenty-two, in substance there are ten and seven,

analyzed: yasmāt na anyat dvayam kāryāt sukha ādi navaka trayam
translated: Because there is no other pair apart from the effect, the three groups of nine beginning with pleasure.

analyzed: nāma sat lakṣaṇa abhāvāt tad nāmnaḥ sārthaka tvataḥ
translated: Because of the absence of the true characteristic of name, because of the meaningfulness of that name,

analyzed: trayāṇām varga vṛtti tve pi artham abhyeṣyate paraiḥ
translated: Even though the three are found in groups, the meaning will be sought by others.

analyzed: viśiṣṭa buddhi hetu tvāt ādhipatya viśeṣataḥ
translated: Because of being the cause of a distinguished cognition, because of the distinction of predominance,

analyzed: kāya indriyāt viśiṣṭa tvam dvayoḥ netra indriya ādi vat
translated: The distinction of the two from the body faculty is like that of the two eye faculties and so on.

analyzed: aiśvarya arthaḥ vipaścidbhiḥ indriya arthaḥ bhidhīyate
translated: The meaning of the word indriya is said by the wise to be the meaning of aiśvarya,

original: svārthavyaktiṣu pañcānāṃ caturṇāṃ tvarthayordvayoḥ // Abhidh //🔽svagocaropalabdhyādāvīśitvamapare viduḥ /
analyzed: sva artha vyaktiṣu pañcānām caturṇām tu arthayoḥ dvayoḥ  sva gocara upalabdhi ādau īśitvam apare viduḥ
translated: In the manifestation of one's own meaning, of the five, but of the four, of the two meanings.🔽Others know that in the perception of one's own domain and so on, there is lordship,

analyzed: sva artha vijñāne eva anye āhuḥ paṇḍita māninaḥ
translated: Others who are proud of being learned say that it is only in the cognition of one's own meaning.

analyzed: kleśa utpattau sukha ādīnām śraddhā ādīnām guṇa āptiṣu
translated: In the arising of afflictions, in the attainment of the qualities of pleasure and so on, of faith and so on,

analyzed: phala saṃkleśa saṃbhāra viśuddhi tvāt anukramaḥ
translated: The order is due to the distinction of result, affliction, accumulation, and purification.

analyzed: sattva ākhyā sattva vaicitryam dhṛtiḥ kleśa udbhavaḥ ca yaiḥ
translated: The faculties are considered to be those by which there is the designation of beings, the variety of beings, support, and the arising of afflictions,

analyzed: mārga upāyaḥ phala prāptiḥ teṣām indriya tā matā
translated: the means of the path, and the attainment of the result.

analyzed: sparśa āśraya udbhava ādhāra saṃbhoga tvāt caturdaśa
translated: And because of being the basis, origin, support, and enjoyment of contact, there are fourteen.

analyzed: svarga apavarga hetu tvāt tad anyat vā indriya aṣṭakam
translated: The other eight faculties are for the sake of heaven and liberation.

analyzed: chandam vīrya aṅga bhūta tvāt sparśaḥ vitti anubṛṃhaṇāt
translated: Desire is not a faculty because it is included in the faculty of energy, and contact is not because it is nourished by feeling.

analyzed: saṃjñā prajñā abhibhūta tvāt na indriyam muniḥ abhyadhāt
translated: The Sage did not declare conceptualization to be a faculty because it is overwhelmed by wisdom.

original: śraddhādīnāṃ vidāṃ caiva doṣaḥ śuddhau malodaye /
analyzed: śraddhā ādīnām vidām ca eva doṣaḥ śuddhau mala udaye
translated: The fault of faith, etc. and of the knowledges, in purification and the arising of defilement,

analyzed: pradhāna tvāt manaskāraḥ na indriyam samudāhṛtam
translated: and because of being primary, attention is not declared to be a faculty.

analyzed: saṃbhāvanā anukūla tvāt adhimokṣaḥ na indriyam
translated: And because of being favorable to conviction, resolve is also not a faculty.

original: kālāntaraphalotpādasaṃdehābhyāṃ na cetanā // Abhidh //🔽nāpramādo 'pyasau vīryāt /🔽na hrīḥ prāgalbhanigrahāt /
analyzed: kāla antara phala utpāda saṃdehābhyām na cetanā  na apramādaḥ pi asau vīryāt  na hrīḥ prāgalbha nigrahāt
translated: And because of doubt about the production of the result at another time, volition is not.🔽And because of being diligence, heedfulness is not.🔽And because of the control of pride, shame is not.

analyzed: na upekṣā nā api ca alobhaḥ vīrya śraddhā abhibhūtitaḥ
translated: And because of being overwhelmed by energy and faith, equanimity and non-greed are not.

analyzed: na prasrabdhiḥ vid autkaṭyāt vinindya tvāt ca na āsravāḥ
translated: Tranquility is not a root because it is not prominent, and because it is blameworthy, it is not a root of the wholesome.

original: jātyādayo na pārārthyāt niṣkriyatvānna nirvṛtiḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: jāti ādayaḥ na pārārthyāt niṣkriya tvāt na nirvṛtiḥ
translated: Birth, etc. are not roots because they are not for the sake of others. Cessation is not a root because it is not an action.

original: kāyasya bādhanaṃ duḥkhaṃ daurmanasyaṃ tu cetasaḥ /
analyzed: kāyasya bādhanam duḥkham daurmanasyam tu cetasaḥ
translated: Pain is the affliction of the body, but mental pain is sorrow.

original: sukhaṃ ca sumanastā ca sātaṃ śārīramānasam // Abhidh //
analyzed: sukham ca sumanastā ca sātam śārīra mānasam
translated: Pleasure and joy are bodily and mental comfort.

analyzed: vaiśiṣṭyāt mānasam sātam sukham kvacid udāhṛtam
translated: In some cases, mental comfort is called pleasure because of its superiority.

analyzed: ṣaṭsu bhūmiṣu vijñeyam nīrajaska ādyam indriyam
translated: The faculties beginning with the absence of passion should be known to exist in six stages.

original: tadanye nirmale tvakṣe draṣṭavye navabhūmike // Abhidh //
analyzed: tad anye nirmale tu akṣe draṣṭavye nava bhūmike
translated: In the pure eye, the other faculties should be seen to exist in nine stages.

analyzed: daurmanasyam dvi hātavyam manaḥ vitti trayam tridhā
translated: Mental pain is to be abandoned by both [paths]. The three [faculties] of the mind are of three kinds.

original: navābhyāsapraheyāṇi dvidhā pañca na tu trayam // Abhidh //
analyzed: nava abhyāsa praheyāṇi dvidhā pañca na tu trayam
translated: Nine are to be abandoned by cultivation alone, but five are of two kinds, not three.

original: pūrvaṃ kramodbhavaiḥ kāme vipāko labhyate dvayam /
analyzed: pūrvam krama udbhavaiḥ kāme vipākaḥ labhyate dvayam
translated: In the first stage, two [faculties] are obtained as results born from the previous stage in the desire realm.

original: anyaiḥ ṣaṭ sapta vāṣṭau vā ṣaḍ rūpe antye tu jīvitam // Abhidh //
analyzed: anyaiḥ ṣaṭ sapta vā aṣṭau vā ṣaṣ rūpe antye tu jīvitam
translated: By others, six, seven, or eight [faculties] are obtained. In the form realm, six [faculties] are obtained. In the last [stage], only the life faculty.

analyzed: mriyamāṇaiḥ nirodhyante trīṇi ante aṣṭau tu madhyame
translated: When dying, three [faculties] cease at the end, but eight in the middle.

original: daśāṣṭau nava catvāri kāme pañca śubhāni vā // Abhidh //
analyzed: daśa aṣṭau nava catvāri kāme pañca śubhāni vā
translated: Ten, eight, nine, and four [are the faculties] in the desire realm, or five pure [faculties].

analyzed: ādi anta lābhaḥ navabhiḥ sapta aṣṭābhiḥ ca madhyayoḥ
translated: The attainment of the first and last [fruits] is by nine [faculties], of the middle two by seven or eight.

analyzed: ekādaśabhiḥ āptiḥ tu phalasya antyasya hānitaḥ
translated: But the attainment of the last fruit is by eleven, due to the loss [of the faculty of] pleasure.

original: svasya dhātoḥ parijñānaṃ svavipakṣadṛśā pathā // Abhidh //
analyzed: svasya dhātoḥ parijñānam sva vipakṣa dṛśā pathā
translated: The complete knowledge of one's own realm is by the path of one's own antidote.

analyzed: kāmadhātu parijñānam prāyas saptabhiḥ iṣyate
translated: The complete knowledge of the desire realm is considered to be mostly by seven [faculties].

analyzed: sa malaiḥ nirmalaiḥ tu arthaiḥ aṣṭābhiḥ abhidhīyate
translated: But it is said to be by eight, with defiled and undefiled faculties.

analyzed: rūpa dhātu parijñānam iṣṭam daśabhiḥ indriyaiḥ
translated: The complete knowledge of the form realm is accepted to be by ten faculties.

analyzed: antya dhātu parijñānam ekādaśabhiḥ ucyate
translated: The complete knowledge of the last realm is said to be by eleven.

analyzed: sarva sattvāḥ tri dhātu sthāḥ upekṣā āyuḥ manaḥ nvitāḥ
translated: All beings in the three realms are endowed with equanimity, life, and mind.

analyzed: tvak strī tva vyañjanaiḥ kāme rūpiṇaḥ cakṣuḥ ādibhiḥ
translated: In the desire realm, they are endowed with the faculties of skin, female, and male. The form realm beings are endowed with the eye and so on.

original: kāminaḥ khalu duḥkhena tadrāgī durmanastayā /🔽ūrdhvajastu sukhenāryaḥ śubhāhvādharajau tathā // Abhidh //
analyzed: kāminaḥ khalu duḥkhena tad rāgī durmanaḥ tayā  ūrdhvajaḥ tu sukhena āryaḥ śubha āhvā adhara jau tathā
translated: Indeed, those in the desire realm are endowed with suffering, because of attachment to that, with mental dissatisfaction.🔽But the noble one born above is endowed with pleasure, and so are those born below, called the good.

analyzed: śubhaiḥ sa śubha mūlakaḥ
translated: The one born below, called the good, is endowed with joy. He is rooted in the good.

analyzed: śaikṣābhyām mokṣa mārga sthau aśaikṣaḥ rhan sva mārga gaḥ
translated: Those abiding in the path of liberation are learners, the arhat who is a non-learner proceeds in his own path.

analyzed: upekṣā āyuḥ manaḥ yuktaḥ vaśyam traya samanvitaḥ
translated: One necessarily possesses three when endowed with equanimity, life, and mind.

analyzed: caturbhiḥ kāya sukhavān cakṣuṣmān api pañcabhiḥ
translated: One possessing body and pleasure possesses four, and also one possessing eyes possesses five.

analyzed: strī indriya ādi anvitaḥ ṣṭābhiḥ duḥkhī yuktaḥ tu saptabhiḥ
translated: One endowed with the female faculty, etc. possesses eight, one who is miserable is endowed with seven.

analyzed: ekādaśabhiḥ antyābhyām sapta ṣaḍbhiḥ tad ādya vān
translated: One possessing the last two possesses eleven, one possessing the first possesses six.

analyzed: tri dvīpa naraka utpannāḥ mithyātva niyatāḥ api
translated: Even those destined for error who are born in the three continents and in hell

analyzed: bahubhiḥ hi eka anna viṃśatyā su alpaiḥ aṣṭābhiḥ anvitāḥ
translated: are endowed with many, with as few as eighteen, and with as many as twenty-nine.
Those in the intermediate state, ghosts, animals, and those following faith

analyzed: tri adhikaiḥ daśabhiḥ yuktāḥ daśabhiḥ vā nava adhikaiḥ
translated: are endowed with ten plus three, or with ten, or with nine plus.

original: samyaktvaniyatā ye tu ye ca śraddhādhimuktikāḥ /
analyzed: samyaktva niyatāḥ ye tu ye ca śraddhā adhimuktikāḥ
translated: But those destined for rightness and those liberated by faith

analyzed: te ekādaśabhiḥ yuktāḥ daśabhiḥ vā nava adhikaiḥ
translated: are endowed with eleven, or with ten, or with nine plus.
The arhat called liberated by wisdom, the body witness, and the one called both ways

analyzed: akṣa ekādaśaka upetāḥ yadi vā aṣṭādaśa anvitāḥ
translated: are endowed with eleven faculties, or with eighteen.

analyzed: kāmadevāḥ mṛtāḥ su alpaiḥ daśabhiḥ saptaka adhikaiḥ
translated: The gods of the desire realm die after a maximum of sixteen thousand years, with a minimum of ten years plus seven.

analyzed: te eva ekonaviṃśatyā yuktāḥ bahubhiḥ indriyaiḥ
translated: Those same [gods] with nineteen [years] plus many faculties.

analyzed: dvis dhyāna jāḥ tu sarva alpaiḥ daśabhiḥ pañcaka adhikaiḥ
translated: But those born in the second dhyāna with the minimum of ten years plus five.

analyzed: daśabhiḥ sa catuṣkaiḥ tu śubhakṛtsnāḥ samanvitāḥ
translated: Those of the Śubhakṛtsna heaven are endowed with ten years plus four.

analyzed: bṛhat phalāḥ hi ati alpaiḥ trayodaśabhiḥ anvitāḥ
translated: The Bṛhatphala gods are endowed with the minimum of thirteen years.

analyzed: yuktāḥ ṣoḍaśabhiḥ tu ete sarva bhūribhiḥ indriyaiḥ
translated: These [gods] are endowed with sixteen [years] plus all the abundant faculties.

analyzed: aṣṭābhiḥ daśabhiḥ sa ekaiḥ ārūpyāḥ su alpa bhūribhiḥ
translated: The formless [gods] with the minimum of eight, with ten plus one.

analyzed: sa deva kauravāḥ sattvāḥ trayodaśabhiḥ anvitāḥ
translated: Beings in the heaven of the gods plus Kuru are endowed with thirteen [years].

analyzed: aṣṭābhiḥ niḥśubhaḥ yuktaḥ daśabhiḥ vā traya adhikaiḥ
translated: The Anāgāmin of the Śuddhāvāsas is endowed with eight or ten [years] plus three.

analyzed: dvi liṅgāḥ paścimaiḥ su alpaiḥ viśati ā api ekayā param
translated: Those of two genders with the minimum of twenty plus one at most.

analyzed: sapta dravya avinirbhāgī paramāṇuḥ bahis gataḥ
translated: The external atom is indivisible into seven substances.

analyzed: kāmeṣu eka adhikaḥ kāye dvi adhikaḥ cakṣuḥ ādiṣu
translated: In the desire realm, the body is one substance more, and the eye, etc. are two substances more.

analyzed: evam rūpe vijñeyaḥ hitvā gandha rasa dvayam
translated: In the form realm, it should be known to be the same, excluding the two: smell and taste.

original: cittaṃ caitasikaiḥ sārdhaṃ saṃskṛtaṃ tu svalakṣaṇaiḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: cittam caitasikaiḥ sārdham saṃskṛtam tu sva lakṣaṇaiḥ
translated: The mind, along with mental factors, is conditioned by its own characteristics.

analyzed: daśa dharmāḥ mahābhaumāḥ vid saṃjñā cetanā smṛtiḥ
translated: The ten dharmas are the great grounds: volition, ideation, volition, mindfulness,

analyzed: chandaḥ sparśaḥ dhi mokṣaḥ ca dhīḥ samādhiḥ manaskṛtiḥ
translated: Desire, contact, determination, wisdom, concentration, and mental activity.

analyzed: śraddhā apekṣā apramādaḥ ca prasrabdhiḥ hrīḥ apatrapā
translated: Faith, respect, heedfulness, tranquility, shame, embarrassment,

analyzed: mūlavīryam ahiṃsā ca śubhabhūkāḥ daśa smṛtāḥ
translated: The roots, vigor, non-violence, and purity are considered the ten grounds of good.

analyzed: styānam pramattiḥ āśraddhyam ālasyam mūḍhiḥ uddhatiḥ
translated: Sloth, negligence, lack of faith, laziness, delusion, and obstruction,

original: kliṣṭe ṣaṭ aśubhe tu dve āhrīkyamanapatrapā // Abhidh //
analyzed: kliṣṭe ṣaṣ aśubhe tu dve āhrīkyam anapatrapā
translated: Six in the defiled, but two in the inauspicious: lack of shame and lack of embarrassment.

analyzed: māyā śāṭhya mada krodha vihiṃsā īrṣyā pradaṣṭayaḥ
translated: Deception, craftiness, conceit, anger, harmfulness, envy, and resentment,

original: sūkṣmopanāhamātsaryāṇyalpakleśabhuvo daśa // Abhidh //🔽pṛthivyādi yathā dravyaṃ nīlādiguṇayogataḥ /
analyzed: sūkṣma upanāha mātsaryāṇi alpa kleśa bhuvaḥ daśa  pṛthivī ādi yathā dravyam nīla ādi guṇa yogataḥ
translated: Subtle resentment and stinginess are the ten grounds of the small defilements.🔽Just as earth, etc. are qualified by various words due to the possession of qualities like blue, etc.,

analyzed: taiḥ taiḥ viśeṣyate śabdaiḥ caitta yogāt manaḥ tathā
translated: So too is the mind by the connection with mental factors.

analyzed: bhūta bhautika nānātvam svarūpa iha ākṛtam yathā
translated: Just as the diversity of elements and derivatives is due to their own nature,

analyzed: tathā eva citta caittānām pṛthaktvam upadhāryatām
translated: So too should the difference between mind and mental factors be understood.

analyzed: yathā saṃbandhi saṃbandhāt vikāraḥ mbhasi lakṣyate
translated: Just as modification is observed in water due to the connection with the connected,

analyzed: tathā saṃsargi saṃsargāt cetaḥ vikṛtiḥ īkṣyatām
translated: so let mental modification be seen due to the association with the associated.

analyzed: guṇaḥ viśeṣaṇam dharmaḥ mātrā vṛttiḥ tathā āśrayī
translated: Qualities, attributes, dharmas, mere occurrence, and basis -

analyzed: iti evamādayaḥ śabdāḥ pradhāna apekṣa vṛttayaḥ
translated: these and other words have their usage dependent on the primary meaning.

analyzed: cittam pradhānam eteṣām vastu mātra graha ādibhiḥ
translated: Mind is primary among these due to grasping mere objects, etc.

analyzed: bījam ca etat pravṛttīnām śuddhi saṃkarayoḥ api
translated: And this is the seed of the activities, even of purification and confusion.

analyzed: abhyudgacchati kāma āptam dharmaiḥ dvādaśabhiḥ saha
translated: The mind of the desire realm arises with twelve dharmas,

analyzed: akliṣṭa avyākṛtam cittam raśmivān iva raśmibhiḥ
translated: like the sun with its rays.

analyzed: tathā aṣṭādaśabhiḥ cittaiḥ nivṛtam jāyate manaḥ
translated: Similarly, the obscured mind arises with eighteen mental factors,

original: dvāviṃśatyā sahāvaśyaṃ śubhaṃ bhavati mānasam // Abhidh //
analyzed: dvāviṃśatyā saha avaśyam śubham bhavati mānasam
translated: the wholesome mental state necessarily arises with twenty-two.

analyzed: cetasoḥ saha viṃśatyā cittam utpadyate śubham
translated: An unwholesome mind arises with twenty mental factors,

analyzed: dṛś moha mātra yuktam yat krodha ādyaiḥ tu adhikam vadet
translated: if it is associated with mere delusion and view, if it is associated with anger etc., one should say more.

analyzed: sarvatra saṃbhavāt middham yatra syāt tatra nirdiśet
translated: Sleepiness can occur everywhere, so it should be indicated where it is.

analyzed: tadvat eva ca kaukṛtyam adhikam gaṇayet kvacid
translated: Similarly, one should count remorse as an additional [factor] in some cases.

analyzed: sa aśubham middha kaukṛtyam rūpadhātau na vidyate
translated: Evil, sleep, and remorse do not exist in the form realm.

analyzed: dhyāna antare vitarkaḥ ca vicāraḥ ca api na upari
translated: In the intermediate dhyāna, and above, there is no vitarka or vicāra.

analyzed: saṃprayuktaḥ saṃskāraḥ sama tā yasya pañcadhā
translated: The formation that is associated is the fivefold equality.

original: viprayuktaśca boddhavyaḥ samatā yasya nāstyasau // Abhidh //🔽viśiṣṭānāmasadbhāvātprasaṃgo nāsti rūpiṇām /

translated: The dissociation should be understood as that which does not have equality.🔽Because the superior ones do not exist, there is no connection with the material ones.

analyzed: saṃskāra grahaṇāt ca eva kha ādīnām na prasajyate
translated: And because of the mention of formations, the elements such as space are not included.

analyzed: prāpti ādayaḥ tu saṃskārāḥ viprayuktāḥ trayodaśa
translated: But the formations dissociated are thirteen, such as acquisition.

analyzed: āpta ukti sva kriyā liṅgāḥ liṅgam eṣām gadiṣyate
translated: The indication of these is said to be by the indication of the words of the adept and one's own action.

analyzed: rāptiḥ samanvitiḥ labdhiḥ dharmavat tā vyavasthitiḥ
translated: Acquisition, possession, attainment, having the dharma, determination,

analyzed: śruta cintā mayānām ca samāpatti dvayasya ca
translated: And of the two attainments born of hearing and reflection,

analyzed: niḥkleśa saṃskṛta apūrvam śubhānām tu rajasvatām
translated: The uncontaminated conditioned, and the previously non-existent, of the wholesome ones with passion,

original: ādilābhe saha prākca tadūrdhvaṃ vā tridheṣyate // Abhidh //
analyzed: ādi lābhe saha prāk ca tad ūrdhvam vā tridhā iṣyate

analyzed: kliṣṭāṇām kuśalānām ca tad anyeṣām tridhā matā

analyzed: nivṛta avyākṛtāḥ jñāna nirmāṇa manasām tathā
translated: The obscured indeterminate, knowledge, magical creation, and mind are also like that.

analyzed: nirvāṇasya āditas lābhe nityasya anyasya sarvadā
translated: When nirvana is first attained, it is eternal, and the other [dharmas] are always.

original: ajā tavartamānā ca kadācittu tridheṣyate // Abhidh //
analyzed: ajā ta vartamānā ca kadācid tu tridhā iṣyate
translated: Sometimes, it is considered to be of three kinds: unborn, present, and past.

original: ekārtharuciheturyaḥ sattvānāṃ sa sabhāgatā /🔽āsaṃjñikaṃ vipāko yaccittopacchedyasaṃjñiṣu // Abhidh //
analyzed: eka artha ruci hetuḥ yaḥ sattvānām sa sabhāgatā  āsaṃjñikam vipākaḥ yat citta upacchedya saṃjñiṣu
translated: That which is the cause of beings' desire for the same object is their homogeneity.🔽The attainment of non-perception is the result for those who have perception that is to be interrupted by mind.

analyzed: śubha asaṃjñi samāpattiḥ dhyāne ntye citta rodhinī
translated: The attainment of the perception of good is in the last dhyana, and it interrupts the mind.

analyzed: niḥsṛti icchā pravṛtti tvāt na āryasya āpyā prayogataḥ
translated: Because of the desire to escape and the engagement, it is not for the noble one, but it is attained through practice.

analyzed: nirodha ākhyā tu vijñeyā vijihīrṣoḥ bhava agra jā
translated: But that which is called cessation should be known as being born from the summit of existence, for one who wishes to rest.

analyzed: śubha āryasya prayogāpyā dvi vedyā niyatā matā
translated: It is considered to be of two kinds of knowledge, and indeterminate, for the noble one, it is attained through practice.

analyzed: cetaḥ catuṣṭaya ayogāt āgamāt upapattitaḥ  nirvedita manaḥ bhāvāt siddhyati iyam acittikā
translated: Because of the non-connection of the four consciousnesses, because of the scriptures, and because of reasoning,🔽This attainment without mind is established because of the absence of the state of mind that desires to rest.

analyzed: gati prajñapti upādānam āyuḥ citta ūṣmaṇoḥ sthitiḥ
translated: The basis for the designation of existence, the life-force, and the continuation of the heat of mind,

analyzed: āgama ādi uktitaḥ ca eva dravyataḥ tat sat iṣyate
translated: It is considered to exist substantially, because of the scriptures and reasoning.

analyzed: jātiḥ sthitiḥ jarā nāśaḥ
translated: Birth, duration, decay, and destruction are the four characteristics of conditioned phenomena.

analyzed: catvāri sthiti nāstitve hetu tva ādi aprasiddhitaḥ
translated: Because of the non-establishment of duration, etc. as causes, etc.

analyzed: śakti hāneḥ jarā siddhiḥ na anya tvāt pariṇāmi tā
translated: The establishment of decay is due to the loss of potentiality, not from transformation due to difference.

analyzed: eka kāritra nāśābhyām śakti hāniḥ
translated: The loss of potentiality is established by the two, simultaneous action and destruction.

analyzed: sati janmani tad bhāvāt dravya kāritra nāśataḥ
translated: Because of the existence of that when there is birth, and because of the destruction of the substance and action,

analyzed: āgamāt upapatteḥ ca vināśaḥ api sa hetukaḥ
translated: Destruction also has a cause, due to scripture and reasoning.

analyzed: vāc śabda adhīna janmānaḥ sva artha pratyāyana kriyāḥ
translated: The actions of expressing one's own meaning, which are born dependent on speech and sound,

analyzed: saṃjñā ādi apara nāmānaḥ trayaḥ nāma ādayaḥ smṛtāḥ
translated: Are known as the three, name, etc., which have other names such as concept, etc.

analyzed: anye nāma ādayaḥ śabdāt aprāpta artha prakāśanāt
translated: Other names, etc. are not eternal, because they reveal the not-yet-known object.

analyzed: anityāḥ te tu vijñeyāḥ sa apekṣā artha vibhāvanāt
translated: But they should be known as impermanent, because they reveal the object in dependence.

analyzed: svarūpam vedayan śabdaḥ vyañjana ādīni ca dhruvam
translated: The word, knowing its own form, and the letters, etc. certainly,

analyzed: artha pratyāyakaḥ
translated: The wise one is said to be the revealer of meaning by the assumption of the nominal.

analyzed: paramāṇu svabhāva tvāt ghoṣa eka tvam na yujyate
translated: The oneness of sound is not proper due to the atomic nature.

original: tādātmyaṃ pratighātitvāt tatsiddhirvaraṇādibhiḥ // Abhidh //🔽sphoṭākhyo nāparo ghoṣācchabdo nityaḥ prasiddhyati /
analyzed: tādātmyam pratighāti tvāt tad siddhiḥ varaṇa ādibhiḥ  sphoṭa ākhyaḥ nā aparaḥ ghoṣāt śabdaḥ nityaḥ prasiddhi ati
translated: Identity is excluded because of resistance. Its establishment is by the Varana and other [winds].🔽A sound called sphota, which is different from the articulated sound, is not established as eternal.

analyzed: krama vṛtteḥ na śabdena kaścid arthaḥ bhidhīyate
translated: By a sound that occurs in sequence, no meaning is expressed.

original: na śrutyā śrūyate śabdastadanyā ca gatiḥ śruteḥ /

analyzed: yaḥ brūyāt sa svam ātmānam vidvadbhiḥ apahāsayet
translated: One who would say this would make himself ridiculed by the wise.

analyzed: pratidyotyam yathāyogam niyata a niyatāḥ ca te
translated: They are determined and undetermined as appropriate.

analyzed: niyata udbhāvanāt buddhaḥ sarvajñaḥ iti gamyate
translated: From the manifestation of the determined, it is understood that the Buddha is omniscient.

analyzed: sattva ākhyāḥ kāmarūpa āptāḥ nisyanda avyākṛtāḥ tathā
translated: Those called sattva, belonging to the desire and form realms, are outflowing and indeterminate,

analyzed: tathā eva ca vipākaḥ ca sābhāgyam prāptayaḥ dvidhā

translated: Because of the absence of the sattva-element and calamity, it does not exist in the fourth [dhyana], according to the sutra.

translated: How can there be permanence due to the destruction of the equality of the celestial palace?🔽Seven [dhyanas] by fire, one by water. When water reaches seven,

translated: then by fire seven times, then by wind one destruction.

analyzed: āgneyāt saptakāt ekaḥ
translated: From the seven beginning with the Āgneya, one is the purifying, and after that,

translated: the life-sustaining, from the Āyusparigraha, the fuel for the life of Śubhakṛtsna.

analyzed: vāta ādi doṣa sādharmyāt sattvānām tad vināśakāḥ
translated: Because of the similarity with the faults of wind and so on, they destroy those of beings.

analyzed: ādhyātmikā iti sārūpyāt na bhū saṃvartanī matā
translated: The outer destruction is not considered to be like the inner one.

analyzed: sattva upapatti hetūnām vipad saṃpad vidhāyinām
translated: The cause of the birth of beings, which brings about their misfortune and prosperity,

analyzed: karma hetuḥ iti iṣyate
translated: and which creates the variety of the world, is considered to be karma.

original: kāyikaṃ vāṅmayaṃ caiva cetanākhyaṃ ca mānasam /
analyzed: kāyikam vāc mayam ca eva cetanā ākhyam ca mānasam
translated: Bodily, verbal, and mental karma, called volition,

analyzed: karmāṇi etāni lokasya kāraṇam na īśvara ādayaḥ
translated: these are the causes of the world, not God and so on.

analyzed: vaiśvarūpyāt krama utpādāt tadvat anyat prasaṅgataḥ
translated: Because of variety, gradual arising, and the consequence of other,

analyzed: karmaṇām bodhyate śaktiḥ vidhi kāla graha ādibhiḥ
translated: The power of karma is recognized through injunctions, time, planets, and so on,

analyzed: pūrve vijñapti avijñaptī cetanā mānasī kriyā

translated: Just as a pot is refined when food is burned in it by fire,

analyzed: saṃvṛt sat dṛṣṭi upetā atas bhikṣu tvam paramārthataḥ

analyzed: vigata avaṇe jñāne buddha ukteḥ mukhya kalpanā
translated: The Buddha's teaching of the knowledge free from defilements is the highest conception.

analyzed: tad āśraye phale ca api vijñeyā guṇa kalpanā
translated: The conception of qualities should be known as based on that, and also on its fruit.

translated: Because of its eternal nature and purity, and because it turns away from all harm,

analyzed: mukhya kalpanayā tadvat dharmaḥ nirvāṇam ucyate

analyzed: āryāḥ śiṣya guṇāḥ saṃghaḥ tathā eva paramārthataḥ
translated: The noble ones and the qualities of disciples are the Sangha, in the same way, in reality.

analyzed: sarvebhyaḥ sattva jātibhyaḥ saṃvaraḥ vā aṅga kāraṇaiḥ
translated: Restraint is from all beings, from all parts, and from all causes.

translated: Restraint is from all beings, from all parts, and from all causes.🔽Non-restraint is obtained by action or by accepting it.

analyzed: avijñaptiḥ atas nyasyāḥ kṣetra aṅga ādi viśeṣataḥ

analyzed: kāma āpta saṃvara tyāgaḥ śikṣā nikṣepaṇa ādibhiḥ

analyzed: tat na iti anye tu ayogataḥ
translated: Some say it is also by downfalls, but others say no, because it is not possible.

analyzed: ayogaḥ na aṃśu vidhvaṃsāt paṭa dravyam vinaśyati
translated: It is not possible, because the cloth is destroyed when the threads are separated.

analyzed: sūtre dhvaṃsa uktiḥ anya arthā yathā īrṣyā śaṭhana ādiṣu
translated: The statement of destruction in the sutra has another meaning, like in the case of envy, deceit, etc.

analyzed: saddharma antarddhitaḥ nye nye na apūrva apratilambhataḥ
translated: Others say it is from the disappearance of the true Dharma, not from obtaining what was not previously obtained.

analyzed: bhū saṃcāreṇa hānyā ca tyajyate dhyāna jam śubham
translated: The wholesome of the dhyanas is relinquished by changing stages and by degeneration.

analyzed: phala āpti akṣa vihānibhiḥ
translated: Similarly, the noble [wholesome] of the formless realm is by obtaining the fruit, by losing the faculties, and by degeneration.

analyzed: asaṃvaraḥ dama prāptiḥ jīvita utsarjanā ā dibhiḥ
translated: Non-restraint is obtained by taming, by giving up life, etc.

analyzed: citta vega ādi vicchedaiḥ avijñaptiḥ tu madhyamā
translated: But the middling non-manifest [karma] is by cutting off the mind's impetus, etc.

analyzed: kāmāptam kuśalam nāma tribhiḥ mūlacchid ādibhiḥ
translated: The wholesome of the desire realm is abandoned by three: by the roots, by cutting off, etc.

analyzed: pratipakṣa udayāt kliṣṭam tridhātu āptam vihīyate
translated: The defiled of the three realms is abandoned by the arising of the antidote.

original: sarve kāmeṣu rūpe dvāveko 'rūpiṣu lābhataḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: sarve kāmeṣu rūpe dvau ekaḥ rūpiṣu lābhataḥ
translated: All in the desire realm, two in the form realm, one in the formless realm, by attainment.

analyzed: yat iṣṭa phala dam karma kuśalam tat udāhṛtam

analyzed: viparyayeṇa akuśalam avyākṛtam atas nyathā
translated: The unwholesome is the opposite of that, the indeterminate is otherwise.

analyzed: kāma āptam prathamam puṇyam apuṇyam aśubha ātmakam
translated: The first wholesome in the desire realm is meritorious, the unwholesome is demeritorious.

analyzed: ūrdhvabhūmikam ānejyam vipākam pratyanejanāt
translated: The unmoving in the higher realms is unmoving in relation to the result, because it does not move.

analyzed: sukha vedyam śubham karma dhyānāt arvāk turīyakāt
translated: Wholesome action that is to be experienced as pleasure is up to the third dhyāna.

analyzed: upekṣā vedyam anyatra duḥkha vedyan tu pāpakam
translated: In other realms, it is to be experienced as equanimity. Unwholesome action is to be experienced as pain.

analyzed: madhyamam karma dhyānena antye pi nirvṛteḥ
translated: Even below, the middle action is in the fourth dhyāna, because it is not produced in the final dhyāna.

analyzed: yugapad tri vipāka iṣṭeḥ dhyāna antara vipākataḥ
translated: Because the result of the intermediate dhyāna is desired to be experienced simultaneously with the three,

analyzed: punar caturvidham karma dṛṣṭa vedya ādi bhedataḥ
translated: Moreover, action is of four kinds, distinguished as to be experienced visually, etc.

analyzed: janmanaḥ tribhiḥ ākṣepaḥ dṛṣṭa dharma āhvayāt ṛte
translated: By three, the projection of birth is from the three, excluding that called the present life.

analyzed: caturṇām api ca ākṣepaḥ sarvatra narakāt ṛte
translated: And the projection of all four is everywhere, except in hell.

original: na tatreṣṭaphalābhāvācchubhaṃ yasmādvipacyate // Abhidh //🔽notpadyavedyakṛttatra yadviraktaḥ pṛthagjanaḥ /🔽sthiro nāparakṛccāryaścalo 'pi bhavamūlayoḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: na tatra iṣṭa phala abhāvāt śubham yasmāt vipacyate  na utpadya vedya kṛt tatra yat viraktaḥ pṛthagjanaḥ  sthiraḥ bhava mūlayoḥ
translated: Because in that realm, wholesome karma does not ripen into a pleasant result due to the absence of desired results.🔽An ordinary person detached from that realm does not create karma to be experienced in the next life.🔽A stable noble one does not create karma to be experienced in the next life, even if unstable.

analyzed: yadā ārtra raudra cittena karma abhīkṣṇam niṣevyate
translated: When an action is frequently performed with a mind of distress or violence,

original: satkṣetre kriyate yacca phalaṃ tasya niyamyate // Abhidh //🔽kṣetrāśayaviśeṣācca phalaṃ sadyo vipacyate /

translated: and when it is done in a good field, the result is determined.🔽And due to the excellence of the field and intention, the result ripens immediately.

translated: And in the case of one arisen from the attainment of cessation, the result is experienced immediately.🔽And that which is determined as the result of karma not to be experienced in this life, due to not being reborn in that realm,

original: tacca dṛṣṭaphalaṃ vidyāt karmādaḥ paripūrakam // Abhidh //
analyzed: tat ca dṛṣṭa phalam vidyāt karma adaḥ paripūrakam
translated: should be known as visible result, and as karma that perfects the other.

analyzed: kuśalasya avicārasya caitasikī eva vedanā
translated: For wholesome karma without investigation, the result is only mental feeling.

original: vipākaḥ kāyikī tviṣṭā duḥkhavedyasya karmaṇaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: vipākaḥ kāyikī tu iṣṭā duḥkha vedyasya karmaṇaḥ
translated: But for unwholesome karma to be experienced as pain, the result is bodily feeling.

analyzed: sa pākam aśubham kṛṣṇam sa pākam rūpa jam sitam
translated: Unwholesome karma with result is black. Wholesome form-realm karma with result is white.

original: śubhāśubhaṃ dvidhā kāme nirmalaṃ tatprahāṇakṛt // Abhidh //
analyzed: śubha aśubham dvidhā kāme nirmalam tad prahāṇa kṛt
translated: In the desire realm, wholesome and unwholesome karma are twofold. The stainless karma is that which causes abandonment.

original: casasro dṛkpathā dṛṣṭau cetanābhāvanāpathāt /🔽ānantaryapathāḥ kāme karmaitatkṛṣṇanāśakṛt // Abhidh //
analyzed: ca sasraḥ dṛkpathāḥ dṛṣṭau cetanā bhāvanā pathāt  ānantarya pathāḥ kāme karma etat kṛṣṇa nāśa kṛt
translated: The uninterrupted paths are the paths of seeing and cultivation, because they are the paths of the absence of conceptualization.🔽In the desire realm, these actions are the destroyer of black [karma].

original: navame cetanā yā tu sā kṛṣṇākṛṣṇayāghātinī /
analyzed: navame cetanā yā tu sā kṛṣṇa akṛṣṇayā āghātinī
translated: And the volition in the ninth [stage] destroys black and white [karma].

original: antānantaryamārgasthā dhyāne dhyāne sitasya tu // Abhidh //
analyzed: anta ānantarya mārga sthāḥ dhyāne dhyāne sitasya tu
translated: In each meditation, the white [karma] of those abiding in the uninterrupted and liberation paths.

analyzed: kāya ādi akuśalam karma sarvam duścaritam matam
translated: All unwholesome actions of body, etc. are considered misconduct.

analyzed: abhidhyā ādīni api trīṇi manaḥ duścarita trayam

analyzed: dveṣeṇa vadha pāruṣya vyāpattīnām samāpanam

analyzed: steyasya anya aṅganā āyāteḥ abhidhyāyāḥ ca lobhataḥ
translated: By greed, stealing and sexual misconduct, and covetousness are completed.

analyzed: mithyādṛśaḥ tu mohena tad anyeṣām tribhiḥ matam
translated: By delusion, wrong view is completed. The other [courses of action] are considered to be completed by all three.

analyzed: caturṇām api adhiṣṭhānam jñeyam eṣām yathākramam
translated: The basis of all four should be known in order,

translated: Killing living beings is intentionally and without error causing another to die.

analyzed: a tyakta anya dhana ādānam adatta ādānam ucyate
translated: Taking what is not given is said to be appropriating the wealth of others without their consent.

analyzed: para strī gamanam kāma mithyā ācāraḥ vikalpavān
translated: Sexual misconduct is having intercourse with the wife of another through desire, with options.

analyzed: artha jñāya anyathāvādaḥ droha buddhyā mṛṣāvacaḥ  dṛṣṭayā śruti ādibhiḥ ca akṣaiḥ manasā yat ca gṛhyate
translated: False speech is speaking untruth with the intention to deceive, knowing the truth.🔽What is grasped by the eyes, ears, etc., and the mind,

analyzed: dṛṣṭam śrutam matam jñātam iti uktam tat yathākramam  paiśunyam bheda kṛt vākyam pāruṣyam tu yat apriyam

translated: Corrupt speech is defiled speech, like singing, storytelling, etc., for others.

analyzed: para sva asat spṛhā abhidhyā vyāpādaḥ sattva gocaraḥ

analyzed: vidveṣa an ananta dṛṣṭiḥ tu mithyādṛṣṭiḥ ahetukā
translated: Hatred is the view of non-existence, but wrong view is without cause.

analyzed: cetanā na kriyā mārgaḥ taiḥ tu sattā pravartate
translated: Intention is not the path of action, but by them existence proceeds.

analyzed: yugapad yāvat aṣṭābhiḥ aśubhaiḥ cetanaiḥ saha

translated: In hell, there are two kinds of lamenting, hatred, and harsh speech.

analyzed: tadvat eva mata abhidhyā mithyādṛṣṭiḥ tathā eva ca
translated: Likewise, covetousness, wrong view, and likewise,

translated: the three beginning with covetousness, and in Kuru, lamenting in two ways.

analyzed: aśubhāḥ tu daśa anyatra sarvatra kuśalāḥ trayaḥ
translated: But the unwholesome ones are elsewhere, and everywhere the three wholesome ones.

analyzed: duḥkha upasaṃhṛteḥ duḥkham alpa āyuḥ tvam tu māraṇāt
translated: Because of the accumulation of suffering, suffering. But because of killing, short life.

analyzed: tejaḥ nāśāt kṛśa ojaḥ tvam idam tat trividham phalam
translated: From the destruction of heat, there is weakness of vitality. This is the threefold result.

analyzed: ānantarya pathe karma phalavat pañcabhiḥ phalaiḥ
translated: Karma on the uninterrupted path, like its result, has five results.

analyzed: caturbhiḥ tu amalena āryam tadvat anyat śabhāśubham
translated: But the noble one with the pure [path] has four, and so does other unwholesome [karma].

original: tato 'nyannirmalaṃ jñeyaṃ tribhiravyākṛtaṃ tathā /🔽phalaṃ śubhasya catvāri dve trīṇi ca śubhādayaḥ // Abhidh //

translated: Then, the other [karma] should be known as pure, and the indeterminate [karma] is also like that with three [results].🔽The result of the wholesome [karma] is four [results], and the wholesome [karmas] and so on are two, three, and four [results].

original: śubhādyāstvaśubhasya dve trīṇi catvāri ca kramāt /
analyzed: śubha ādyāḥ tu aśubhasya dve trīṇi catvāri ca kramāt
translated: But the unwholesome [karma] of the wholesome [karmas] and so on is two, three, and four [results] in order.

analyzed: avyākṛtasya te tu dve trīṇi trīṇi śubha ādayaḥ

analyzed: sarve catvāri atītasya madhyamasya ca bhāvinaḥ
translated: All [karmas] of the past and the present of the future have four [results].

analyzed: madhyamā dve svakasya eva trīṇi anāgāmi janmanaḥ
translated: The middle [karmas] are two [results] of one's own, and the three [results] of the future birth.

analyzed: catvāri eka bhuvaḥ dve vā trīṇi ca apara bhūmikāḥ
translated: The [karmas] of one realm have four or two [results], and the [karmas] of other realms have three [results].

analyzed: śaikṣa ādyāḥ trīṇi śaikṣasya te eva aśaikṣa karmaṇaḥ
translated: The three [karmas] of the trainee and so on are the three of the trainee, and those same [karmas] are of the non-trainee.

original: ekaṃ trīṇi dvayaṃ caiva śaikṣādyāḥ paścimasya tu /
analyzed: ekam trīṇi dvayam ca eva śaikṣa ādyāḥ paścimasya tu
translated: One, three, and two are of the last [karma] of the trainee and so on.

original: dve dve pañca yathāsaṃkhyaṃ dṛggheyasya tu karmaṇaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: dve dve pañca yathāsaṃkhyam dṛś heyasya tu karmaṇaḥ

original: trīṇi catvāri caikaṃ ca dṛṣṭiheyādayaḥ smṛtāḥ /🔽te tvabhyāsapraheyasya dve catvāri tridhā matāḥ // Abhidh //

translated: Three, four, and one are considered to be abandoned by seeing and so on.🔽But those belong to the karma to be abandoned by cultivation, two, four, and three are considered in three ways.

analyzed: kramāt eka dvi catvāri te tu aheyasya karmaṇaḥ
translated: One, two, and four, respectively, belong to the karma not to be abandoned.

analyzed: ekena ākṣipyate janma bhūribhiḥ paripūryate
translated: One birth is projected by one, but is completed by many.

analyzed: kuśalam vā athavā pāpam yat atītam dadat phalam
translated: The good or evil karma that has already passed and is giving its fruit,

original: svaṃ kāyavāṅmanaskarma sā karmasvakatā matā // Abhidh //
analyzed: svam kāya vāc manaḥ karma sā karma svaka tā matā
translated: that is considered to be one's own karma of body, speech, and mind.

analyzed: saṃvṛtyā skandha santāne tad kriyā phala darśanāt
translated: Conventionally, in the continuum of aggregates, the performance of that action and the appearance of its fruit are seen.

analyzed: kartṛ tā bhoktṛ tā ca uktā niṣiddhā śāśvatasya tu

analyzed: syāt karma svaka tā na asti tasya ca iti catuṣkikā

analyzed: prathamā tad phala sthasya vihānāt tasya karmaṇaḥ

analyzed: dvitīyā tad phala sthasya karmaṇā tena ca anvayāt
translated: The second is for one abiding in its fruit, due to the connection with that karma.

analyzed: tṛtīyā ubhaya yuktasya caturthī anubhayasya tu
translated: The third is for one endowed with both, the fourth is for one not endowed with either.

analyzed: dvitīyā dhruva pākasya tad vipāka anavasthite
translated: The second is of the karma that is certain to be experienced, but its result is not fixed.

analyzed: ādyāḥ datta vipākena niruddha anāgata ādinā
translated: The first is when the karma that has given its result has ceased, or is future, etc.

analyzed: dvitīyā tu vihīnena dhruva pākena karmaṇā
translated: But the second is with the karma that is certain to be experienced, but has been abandoned.

translated: The mental defilements are abandoned by the stainless [absorptions] of the meditations and formless [absorptions].

analyzed: adhas bhūmeḥ tu labhyante sāmantaiḥ api śuddhakaiḥ
translated: But the pure [absorptions] of the neighboring stages are also obtained for the lower realms.

analyzed: sa vitarka vicāra ādyāḥ trayaḥ proktāḥ samādhayaḥ
translated: The three concentrations are said to be with initial and sustained thought, etc.

original: dhyānāntare sa cārodhaḥ sadvayo 'nyatra nirdvayaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: dhyāna antare sa ca ārodhaḥ sa dvayaḥ nyatra nirdvayaḥ
translated: In the intermediate meditation, there is initial and sustained thought, with obstruction, and with impurity. Elsewhere, it is without duality.

analyzed: sa āsrava anāsravaḥ ca anye ekādaśa bhuvaḥ trayaḥ
translated: The other [concentration] is both with and without outflows, and is in the three realms and eleven stages.

analyzed: ārya ākāra mati dyotāḥ śūnyatā ādyaḥ samādhayaḥ
translated: The concentrations beginning with emptiness, etc., are illuminated by the superior aspects of the noble ones.

analyzed: daśa apraṇihita ākārāḥ śūnyatāyāḥ dvayam matam
translated: The ten [concentrations] are without expectancy. Two are considered to be of emptiness.

original: animitto 'mṛtākāraiścaturbhiḥ saṃpravartate // Abhidh //🔽vimukterdviprakārāyāḥ prāptaye nirmalāḥ punaḥ /
analyzed: animittaḥ mṛta ākāraiḥ caturbhiḥ saṃpravartate  vimukteḥ dvi prakārāyāḥ prāptaye nirmalāḥ punar
translated: It proceeds with four aspects of the signless and the aspect of cessation.🔽Again, the pure ones are for the attainment of the two kinds of liberation.

analyzed: vimokṣa sumu
translated: The liberation gate is threefold.

analyzed: kha śabdena te eva āviṣkṛtāḥ trayaḥ
translated: By the word gate, those very three are revealed.
The three others have the name of concentration, such as emptiness-emptiness, etc.

analyzed: dvayam ālambate śaikṣam śūnyatas nityatas tathā
translated: The non-learner takes two as its object, as empty and impermanent.

analyzed: kṣayam apratisaṃkhyā ākhyam antyaḥ gṛhṇāti śāntataḥ
translated: The last one takes cessation as its object, considering it as peaceful.

analyzed: ekādaśa bhuvaḥ sarve sa āsravāḥ nṛṣu akopinaḥ
translated: All of the eleven stages are with-outflows, and are in the human realm, not in the formless realm.

analyzed: samādhi bhāvanā dhyānam sukhāya prathamam śubham
translated: The first meditation is good for the sake of happiness.

analyzed: darśanāya akṣi abhijñā uktā prajñā bhedāya yātnikāḥ
translated: The supernormal powers are said to be for the sake of seeing. Those who strive are for the sake of discriminating wisdom.

analyzed: yaḥ ntyaḥ vajra upame dhyāne sarva kleśa kṣayāya sā
translated: That which is the last in the diamond-like concentration is for the sake of the destruction of all defilements.

analyzed: sūtram ca etat samākhyātam buddhena ātma upanāyikam
translated: And this sutra was spoken by the Buddha for the sake of himself.

analyzed: caturṇām apramāṇānām maitrī a dveṣaḥ tathā kṛpā
translated: Of the four immeasurables, friendliness is non-hatred, and so is compassion.

analyzed: muditā prītiḥ ekeṣām upekṣā lobhaḥ iṣyate
translated: Joy is non-greed, and equanimity is non-greed.

analyzed: vyāpādasya vihiṃsāyāḥ arateḥ tṛṣ dviṣaḥ tathā
translated: The antidotes to malice, violence, discontent, thirst, and hatred are explained as follows:

analyzed: pratipakṣaḥ yama ākhyātaḥ damana artham sva cetasaḥ
translated: This is declared to be the antidote for the purpose of controlling one's own mind.

analyzed: sukha ādhāne sukhā maitrī duḥkha nāśa unmukhī kṛpā
translated: In the cultivation of happiness, loving-kindness is happiness. Compassion is inclined towards the destruction of suffering.

original: muditā modanānimnā sattvā ebhyeva paścimā // Abhidh //
analyzed: muditāḥ sattvāḥ ebhyaḥ eva paścimā
translated: Sympathetic joy is joy. Equanimity is the last of these, due to beings themselves.

analyzed: draṣṭavyā vṛttiḥ eteṣām ākāraiḥ sukhita ādi bhiḥ
translated: Their function should be seen through the aspects of being happy, etc.

analyzed: ebhyaḥ tu anyatamena api brahma sāyujyam aśnute
translated: But by any one of these, one attains union with Brahma.

analyzed: nṛṣu kāma avalambīni dhyānayoḥ muditā āhvayoḥ
translated: In humans, those based on desire are called sympathetic joy in the two meditations.

analyzed: ṣaḍ bhaumāni tad anyāni kecid icchanti saptasu
translated: Some wish that the others are in the seven, in six stages.

analyzed: vimokṣāḥ kathitāḥ aṣṭau teṣām dvau aśubha ātmakau
translated: The eight liberations are declared. Two of them have the nature of impurity.

analyzed: tāvādya dhyānayoḥ antye tṛtīyaḥ lobha lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Those two are in the first and last meditations. The third is characterized by non-greed.

analyzed: catvāraḥ vimokṣa ākhyā samāhitāḥ
translated: The four wholesome formless liberations are called concentrations.

analyzed: nirodha ākhya samāpattiḥ vimokṣaḥ
translated: The attainment called cessation is declared to be the eighth liberation.

analyzed: tasyāḥ tu saṃmukhībhāvaḥ sūkṣma sūkṣmāt anantaram
translated: But its actualization is immediately after the subtler and subtlest.

original: vyutthānacittamapyasyāḥ svaṃ śuddhaṃ nirmalaṃ tvadhaḥ // Abhidh //
analyzed: vyutthāna cittam api asyāḥ svam śuddham nirmalam tu adhas
translated: The emerging mind of this [attainment] is also its own pure and stainless [mind], but below [the fourth concentration].

analyzed: kāmāvacara dṛśya arthāḥ vimokṣāḥ prathamāḥ trayaḥ
translated: The first three liberations are of the desire realm, with visible objects.

analyzed: anye tu anvaya dhī pakṣa sva ūrdhva duḥkha ādi avekṣiṇāḥ  sūtre bhi bhava saṃjñā ākhyam proktam āyatana aṣṭakam
translated: The others, however, are with the aspect of subsequent cognition, observing suffering, etc., in higher [realms].🔽In the sutra, the set of eight bases called the liberations is mentioned.

analyzed: vimokṣa adhika vṛtti etat citta aiśvarya pradarśakam
translated: This [set of eight] is taught for the purpose of demonstrating the mastery of mind, with a function superior to the liberations.
